Questions.QuestionString: 20. Which of the following are advantages of using microballoons in repairs to laminate honeycomb sandwich panels?. (Level 2)
Answers: A. Greater concentrations of resin in edges and corners, improved strength to weight ratio, less density, lower stress concentrations.
B. Less density, lower stress concentrations.
C. Improved strength to weight ratio, less density, lower stress.

B.  The overall length of a bolt (from under the head) and the overall length of a screw (including the head).
C.  The length of thread for a bolt, overall length for a countersunk screw.

Questions.QuestionString: 1. How many times can a locking plate be used?. (Level 1)
Answers: A.  indefinitely providing it is a good fit around the component to be locked.

Questions.QuestionString: 2. The taper of a standard taper pin is. (Level 1)

Questions.QuestionString: 5. Wire locking approach angles should not be less than. (Level 1)
6. A spring type washer when used on an aluminium component must be used.
1. A non metallic locknut is. (Level 2)
2. Which can be re-used?. (Level 2)
Answers: A.  Locking plate, circlip, spring washer.
B.  Shake proof washer, spring washer, locking plate.
C.  Tab washer, circlip, locking plate.

Questions.QuestionString: 3. A tab washer has been removed after fitment for a short time from a non essential system, the tab washer may be. (Level 2)
Answers: B.  re-used if a spare is not available.

Questions.QuestionString: 4. Taper pins are subject to what loads?. (Level 2)
5. A turnbuckle locknut is a. (Level 2)
6. A spring washer. (Level 2)
Answers: A.  may be used a second time provided it is fitted the reverse way round.
B.  maybe used more than once provided it continues to provide an efficient lock.
C.  must not be used more than once.

Questions.QuestionString: 7. An internal circlip can be used to. (Level 2)
Answers: A. retain a ball bearing in a housing.
B.  to do both of the above.
C.  retain a ball bearing on a shaft.

Questions.QuestionString: 8. A washer having both twisted teeth and spring actions is. (Level 2)
9. Split pins. (Level 2)
Answers: A.  may be used only once.
B.  can be used more than once but depends on the material of the split pin.
C.  may be used more than once.

Questions.QuestionString: 10. How is the locking feature of the fibre-type locknut obtained?. (Level 2)
Answers: A. By a fibre insert held firmly in place at the base of the load carrying section.
B.  By the use of an unthreaded fibre locking insert.
C.  By making the threads in the fibre insert slightly smaller than those in the load carrying section.

Questions.QuestionString: 11. Split pins are made from. (Level 2)
Answers: A.  brass or Low carbon steel - cadmium plated,.
C.  Low carbon steel - cadmium plated, or stainless steel.

Questions.QuestionString: 1. Forming a solution treated rivet gives it 75% of its hardness. What gives it the other 25%?. (Level 1)
Answers: A.  Leave at room temperature for four hours.
B.  Precipitation treat the component when forming is complete.
C.  Put them in a refrigerator.

Questions.QuestionString: 2. If D or DD rivets are not formed in time , or removed from the freezer in time, they. (Level 1)
Answers: B.  must be re-heat treated before use.
C.  can be re-heat treated once then discarded.

Questions.QuestionString: 3. A joggle in a removed rivet is indication of what type of partial failure?. (Level 1)
4. How is a British aluminium rivet identified?. (Level 1)
5. A BS rivet made from L36 would be what colour and marking?. (Level 1)
Answers: B.  Natural anodic with no marking.

Questions.QuestionString: 6. D and DD rivets are refrigerated to. (Level 1)
7. What do you do to 2017 and 2024 rivets after heat treatment?. (Level 1)
Answers: A.  Leave for a minimum of 2 hours before using.
B.  refrigerate for a minimum of 2 hours before using.

Questions.QuestionString: 8. An American rivet with a cross on the head is. (Level 1)
9. A countersunk rivet of the ‘SP’ series has a head style of. (Level 1)
10. A rivet with no marking has the material code. (Level 2)
11. Rivet MS20426 has what head type?. (Level 2)

Answers: A.  The area of contact between the two sheets of metal when joining by rivets.
B.  The distance between the hole and the edge of the material.
C.  The distance between two holes.

Questions.QuestionString: 13. The length of solid rivets is in graduations of. (Level 3)
14. What would be the diameter and length of a solid rivet if the following markings are given, AS 162-408?. (Level 3)
Answers: A. ¼ inch dia, ½ inch length.
B.  ½ inch dia, 1 inch length.
C.  1/8 inch dia, ½ inch length.

Questions.QuestionString: 15. What would the marking .5 indicate after the normal part number of a solid rivet?. (Level 3)
Answers: A.  The rivet length in graduations of 1/8 inch.
B.  The diameter of the rivet is half an inch.

Questions.QuestionString: 16. What is the pressure range for the Avdel Riveter type F?. (Level 3)

Questions.QuestionString: 20. A chobert rivet gun may be used. (Level 3)

C.  remains in the rivet sleeve to provide mechanical strength.

Answers: A. between the outer faces of the union nuts.
B.  between the extremities of the two nipples.

Questions.QuestionString: 5. Metal tubing fluid lines are sized by wall thickness and. (Level 2)
Answers: A. outside diameter and 1/32 inch increments.
B.  inside diameter and 1/16 inch increments.
C.  outside diameter and 1/16 inch increments.

Questions.QuestionString: 6. A certain amount of slack must be left in a flexible hose during installation because, when under pressure, it. (Level 2)
Answers: A. expands in length and contracts in diameter.
B. contracts in length and expands in diameter.
C. expands in length and diameter.

Questions.QuestionString: 7. The term 'cold flow' is generally associated with. (Level 2)
8. Flexible lines must be fitted with a slack. (Level 2)
Answers: B.  of at least 10 - 12 % of the length.
C.  to allow maximum flexing during operation.

Questions.QuestionString: 9. The material specifications for a certain aircraft require that a replacement oil line be fabricated from3/4 inch, 0.072 5052-0 aluminium alloy tubing. What is the inside dimension of this tubing?. (Level 2)
1. How do you assemble a banjo hose?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. Put a washer on the outside of the banjo only.
B.  Put a washer on the inside of the banjo only.
C.  Put washer either side of the banjo.

Questions.QuestionString: 2. A 0.5 in. diameter pipe is to be joined using standard nuts and fittings. What coupling would you use?. (Level 1)
3. To install a flareless coupling. (Level 1)
Answers: A. turn until torque is felt plus 3 flats (half turn).
C.  turn until torque is felt plus 2 flats.

Questions.QuestionString: 4. A Skydrol hydraulic seal would be made of. (Level 1)
Answers: A.  butyl rubber, ethelene propylene or Teflon Phosphate Ester based.

Questions.QuestionString: 5. Adapter nipples are not required on. (Level 1)
Answers: A. pipe to externally coned adapter.
C.  pipe to internally coned adapter.

Questions.QuestionString: 6. A butyl rubber seal is made from. (Level 2)
7. What is the colour of an AN steel flared-tube fitting?. (Level 2)
8. Which statement about Military Standard (MS) flareless fittings is correct?.
Answers: A.  During installation, MS flareless fittings are normally tightened by turning the nut a specified amount after the sleeve and fitting sealing surface have made contact, rather than being torqued.
B.  MS flareless fittings must be tightened to a specific torque.
C.  MS flareless fittings should not be lubricated prior to assembly.

Questions.QuestionString: 9. A flexible sealing element subject to motion is a. (Level 2)
1. Coil springs are made from. (Level 1)
Answers: A. carbon or alloy steels with high working stress.
B.  low carbon steels with high working stress.
C.  carbon or high alloy steels with low working stress.

Questions.QuestionString: 2. What load are spring hooks subjected to?. (Level 1)
3. Steel music wire is. (Level 2)
Answers: A.  used for lower strength springs.
B.  made of high carbon or nickel alloy.
C.  used for high strength springs and as progressive-rate springs.

Questions.QuestionString: 4. A spring should be inspected for correct. (Level 2)
1. Needle roller bearings. (Level 1)
Answers: A.  can accept a small amount of misalignment.
C.  are designed to carry axial loads.

Questions.QuestionString: 2. When rotating a ball bearing by hand, a regular click indicates. (Level 1)
Answers: C.  intergranular corrosion in the outer ring.

Questions.QuestionString: 3. A journal load is. (Level 1)
4. What kind of bearing is used in a landing system?. (Level 1)
5. Spherical roller bearings resist what loads?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. Large radial but no thrust.
B.  Large radial and moderate thrust.
C.  Large thrust and moderate radial.

Questions.QuestionString: 6. Where are needle roller bearings used?. (Level 1)
Answers: B.  Where is fluid damped bearing used.
C.  Where there are space restrictions.

Questions.QuestionString: 7. Loads on tapered roller bearings are. (Level 1)
8. A crankshaft would be fitted with a. (Level 1)
9. Where heat is likely to be transmitted through a bearing. (Level 2)
10. Shielded ball bearings are inspected by. (Level 2)
Answers: A. running at operating speed and listening for signs of wear.

Questions.QuestionString: 11. Thrust bearings take. (Level 2)
12. A single row ball bearing is best suited to accepting. (Level 2)
13. Taper roller bearings are used for which of the following purposes?. (Level 2)
Answers: A. To transmit radial loads whilst resisting axial movement.
B.  To transmit thrust loads with radial loads.
C.  To permit axial movement whilst resisting radial load.

Questions.QuestionString: 14. The stationary race of a journal bearing is normally. (Level 2)
15. Inspection of bearings is normally carried out. (Level 2)
Answers: C.  when removed from an assembly.

Questions.QuestionString: 1. How do you check a chain for elongation?. (Level 1)
Answers: A.  Apply a load, measure chain and use 5% max formula to check extension.
B.  Apply a load, measure chain and use 2% max formula to check extension.
C.  Hang the chain under its own weight, measure chain and use 2% max formula to check extension.

Questions.QuestionString: 2. How do you store a chain?. (Level 1)
Answers: A.  Oiled and coiled in greaseproof paper.
B.  Lay uncoiled and flat in greaseproof paper.
C.  Hanged so they do not kink.

Questions.QuestionString: 3. Epicyclic gears are used on. (Level 1)
Answers: A.  shafts rotating on axis 90 degrees from each other.
B.  shafts rotating on the same axis.
C.  shafts rotating on offset axis.

Questions.QuestionString: 4. What is the purpose of the guard, where a control chain goes around a sprocket?. (Level 1)
Answers: A.  Stops the chain coming off if it goes slack.
B.  Protects personnel when carrying out maintenance.
C.  Prevents entry of foreign bodies.

Questions.QuestionString: 5. Worm drives operate in shafts which are. (Level 1)
Answers: A. 90 degrees to each other and in a differing plane.
B.  90 degrees to each other and in the same plane.
C.  parallel to each other and in the same plane.

Questions.QuestionString: 6. The pattern of a gear is the. (Level 1)
Answers: A. the path they take when the gear is rotating.
B.  profile of the gear teeth.
C.  mark it leaves on a mating gear.

Questions.QuestionString: 7. A worm drive creates. (Level 2)
Answers: A.  a drive in 2 planes and transmits both directions.
B.  a drive in 1 plane but transmits both directions.
C.  a drive in 2 planes but transmits 1 direction only.

Questions.QuestionString: 8. The teeth of a gear would normally be. (Level 2)
9. If a chain is removed for routine maintenance. (Level 2)
Answers: A. it must be proof checked to full load.
B.  it must be proof checked to ½ max load.
C.  it does not have to be proof checked.

Questions.QuestionString: 10. On gear teeth, the wear pattern should be. (Level 2)
Answers: A. the middle of the tooth most worn.
B.  even from top to bottom.
C.  the top edge most worn.

Questions.QuestionString: 11. On bevel gear teeth, the wear pattern should be. (Level 2)
Answers: A. at the centre of the tooth.
B.  greatest at the heel, least at the toe.
C.  greatest at the toe, tapering off to the heel.

Questions.QuestionString: 12. Bevel gears are. (Level 2)
13. A chain is checked for stiff links by. (Level 2)
Answers: A. hanging by hand by measure and sight.
C.  running the chain over a finger by 180 degrees.

Questions.QuestionString: 1. When is a turnbuckle not in safety?. (Level 1)
Answers: A.  When a small diameter wire can be passed through the inspection hole.
B.  When you can see daylight through the hole.
C.  When a wire of the same diameter as the inspection hole can be passed through.

Questions.QuestionString: 2. How do you check a turnbuckle is in safety?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. Use the inspection hole or count the threads showing.
B.  Ensure that the turnbuckle cannot be turned by hand.
C.  Make sure no threads are showing at either end of the turnbuckle.

Questions.QuestionString: 3. British aircraft cables are classified by their. (Level 1)
Answers: B.  breaking loads in lbf, where 1 lbf = 4.448N.
C.  diameter and breaking load in Hundredweights.

Questions.QuestionString: 4. Cables are preferred to other control systems because. (Level 1)
Answers: A. single braid allows for 2 way directions.
B.  they are strong and light.
C.  they maintain slight mechanical advantage over push/pull systems.

Questions.QuestionString: 5. Turnbuckles, depending on type, are locked by. (Level 1)
6. Cable tension is maintained by. (Level 1)
7. To correctly tension cables it can help to. (Level 1)
Answers: A. take up initial slack by additional pulleys.
B.  have control surface locks in to support weight and adjust turnbuckles equally.
C.  use a cable run with turnbuckles at least every eight feet.

Questions.QuestionString: 8. British turnbuckles are checked for safety by. (Level 1)
Answers: A.  attempting to pass a hardened pin probe through the inspection hole.
B.  attempting to pass locking wire through the hole.
C.  looking through the hole and checking for threads showing.

Questions.QuestionString: 9. Turnbuckles are correctly fitted when. (Level 1)
Answers: A.  both rods are seen to touch in the inspection hole.
B.  both rods enter the barrel by the same amount.
C.  the inspection hole is blind or the required number of threads are showing.

Questions.QuestionString: 10. How is the diameter of a cable measured?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. Diameter of one wire multiplied by the number of wires.
C.  Diameter of one wire only.

Questions.QuestionString: 11. What is the small hole on a swaged turnbuckle for?. (Level 2)
Answers: A. To check for moisture deposits.
B.  To check if correct amount of cable has been inserted before swaging.
C.  To alloy the turnbuckle to be wire locked.

Questions.QuestionString: 12. When checking the safety of turnbuckles you should use what?. (Level 2)
Answers: B.  Wire the same diameter as the inspection hole.
C.  Wire smaller than inspection hole.

Questions.QuestionString: 13. Cable minimum breakage strain for British and American is measured by.
Answers: A.  hundredweight for British, c.s.a. and pounds for American.
B.  hundredweight for British, c.s.a. hundredweight for American.

Questions.QuestionString: 14. If a pulley shows signs of wear on one side. (Level 2)
Answers: A. the cable is too tightly tensed.
B.  the pulley is too large for the cable.

Questions.QuestionString: 15. A 7x7 cable has seven strands each of. (Level 2)
16. Cable stops are manufactured from. (Level 2)
17. Pulleys are manufactured from. (Level 2)
Answers: B.  tungum and high tensile steel.

Questions.QuestionString: 18. In a Teleflex flexible control system, the Teleflex cable consists of. (Level 2)
Answers: A.           multi strand steel wires and is used primarily as a single one way device operated from a control lever.
B.           a high tensile steel wire with a right or left hand helix wire wound on to it. The system can operate in two directions.
C.           a flexible seven or nineteen strand steel cable used for the operation of manual flying controls.

Questions.QuestionString: 19. A cable tension regulator will be installed in a flying control system to. (Level 2)
Answers: A.  automatically compensate for low cable tension caused by worn cables.
B.  compensate for rapid movement of the controls by taking up the slack.
C.  allow for variations in temperature which will vary the cable tension.

Questions.QuestionString: 20. Aircraft flying control cables are normally classified by the. (Level 2)
Answers: A. circumference of the cable and overall length.
B.  number of strands it contains and the number of wires in each strand.
C.  minimum breaking load or the diameter in inches.

Questions.QuestionString: 21. 7 * 7 cable has seven stranded wires each with. (Level 2)
22. Tension regulators on aeroplanes with fully metal bodies are used to. (Level 2)
Answers: A.  set up the necessary tension.
C.  relax the tension in cold conditions.

Questions.QuestionString: 1. A 14 gauge cable when compared to an 18 gauge cable has. (Level 1)
2. In a front release connector, the pin will be. (Level 1)
Answers: A. released from the front and extracted from the rear.
B.  released from rear and extracted from the front.
C.  released from the front and extracted from the front.

Questions.QuestionString: 3. An interconnect cable has what insulation?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. same thickness as airframe cable.

Questions.QuestionString: 4. Why is the ground side of an electrical power conductor usually connected to a male connector?. (Level 1)
Answers: A.  To make installation of the connector easier.
B.  To reduce the chance of an accidental short.
C.  To reduce the chance of corrosion affecting the pins.

Questions.QuestionString: 5. Maximum temperature of tin coated copper cable is. (Level 1)
6. Plug pins are numbered. (Level 1)
Answers: A. from the outside in - clockwise.
B. from the inside out - clockwise.
C. from the inside out - anticlockwise.

Questions.QuestionString: 7. Equipment wire. (Level 1)
Answers: A.  is flexible and suitable for soldering.
B.  can be used for interconnect wiring.
C.  has thicker insulation than interconnect wire.

B.  weight for weight it can carry more signal.

Questions.QuestionString: 16. Interconnect cables. (Level 2)
Answers: A.  employ thinner insulation than airframe types.
B.  are used for equipment wire in the unified system.
C.  are the cable through the MEC to the engine.

Questions.QuestionString: 17. The first step for the coaxial cable to attach to the end fitting is. (Level 2)
Answers: A.  use a tooling hold between the assembly and cable.
B.  the outer covering is cut back to expose the braided outer conductors.
C.  back-off the insulator and connect with conductor.

Questions.QuestionString: 18. A fire resistant cable must maintain adequate insulation in a fire for. (Level 2)
19. When silver coated connectors are used in unpressurised parts of the aircraft.
Answers: A.  wet track arcing can occur.
C.  separation of the coating can occur.

Questions.QuestionString: 20. Knuckling is a problem on earlier aircraft cables due to. (Level 2)
Answers: C.  wires being pulled through too hard.

Questions.QuestionString: 21. Cable current ratings are based on a conductor temperature rise of 40  °C and if the maximum design ambient temperature is continuously exceeded they should be. (Level 2)
22. Which of the following types of electrical wire is likely to be used for connection of thermo-couples around the jet-pipe of a turbine engine?. (Level 2)
23. The main reason why crimped joints are preferable to soldered joints is.
Answers: A.  the quality of crimped joints will be constant.
C.  there is no heat required.

Questions.QuestionString: 24. In the cable identification '2 P 215 A 28 N' the position of the letter P indicates. (Level 2)
Answers: A.  that it is a Pneumatics system cable.
C.  which segment the cable is in.

Questions.QuestionString: 25. Crimping terminals are colour coded. The colour indicates. (Level 2)
Answers: A. the type of crimping tool to be used only.
B.  the wire size to be used with that crimp only.
C.  both the crimping tool and the size of the wire to be used.
